comment:
The PrintableUri component inherits from the ResultLink component and supports all of its options. This component displays the URI, or path, to access a result.

This component is a result template component (see Result Templates).

name: PrintableUri.options
comment: The options for the ResultLink

name: PrintableUri.options.alwaysOpenInNewWindow
comment:
Specifies whether the component should open its link in a new window instead of opening it in the current context. If this option is true, clicking the ResultLink calls the openLinkInNewWindow method instead of the openLink method.

Note:

If a search page contains a ResultPreferences component whose enableOpenInNewWindow option is true, and the end user checks the Always open results in new window box, ResultLink components in this page will always open their links in a new window when the end user clicks them, no matter what the value of their alwaysOpenInNewWindow option is.

Default value is false.

name: PrintableUri.options.field
comment:
Specifies the field to use to output the component href attribute value. Tip:

Instead of specifying a value for the field option, you can directly add an href attribute to the ResultLink HTML element. Then, you can use a custom script to generate the href value.

Examples:

  • With the following markup, the ResultLink outputs its href value using the @uri field (rather than the default field):
<a class="CoveoResultLink" field="@uri"></a>
  • In the following result template, the custom getMyKBUri() function provides the href value:
<script id="KnowledgeArticle" type="text/underscore" class="result-template">
  <div class='CoveoIcon>'></div>
  <a class="CoveoResultLink" href="<%= getMyKBUri(raw) %>"></a>
  <div class="CoveoExcerpt"></div>
</script>

See also hrefTemplate, which can override this option.

By default, the component uses the @clickUri field of the item to output the value of its href attribute.

name: PrintableUri.options.hrefTemplate
comment:
Specifies a template literal from which to generate the ResultLink href attribute value (see Template literals). This option overrides the field option value.

The template literal can reference any number of fields from the parent result. It can also reference global scope properties.

Examples:

  • The following markup generates an href value such as http://uri.com?id=itemTitle:
<a class='CoveoResultLink' data-href-template='${clickUri}?id=${title}'></a>
  • The following markup generates an href value such as localhost/fooBar:
<a class='CoveoResultLink' data-href-template='${window.location.hostname}/{Foo.Bar}'></a>

Default value is undefined.

name: PrintableUri.options.onClick
comment:
Specifies an event handler function to execute when the user clicks the ResultLink component. The handler function takes a JavaScript Event object and an IQueryResult as its parameters.

Overriding the default behavior of the onClick event can allow you to execute specific code instead.

Note:

You cannot set this option directly in the component markup as an HTML attribute. You must either set it in the init call of your search interface (see Components - Passing Component Options in the init Call), or before the init call, using the options top-level function (see Components - Passing Component Options Before the init Call).

Example:




// You can set the option in the 'init' call:
Coveo.init(document.querySelector("#search"), {
  ResultLink : {
    onClick : function(e, result) {
      e.preventDefault();
      // Custom code to execute with the item URI and title.
      openUriInASpecialTab(result.clickUri, result.title);
    }
  }
});

// Or before the 'init' call, using the 'options' top-level function:
// Coveo.options(document.querySelector('#search'), {
//   ResultLink : {
//     onClick : function(e, result) {
//       e.preventDefault();
//       // Custom code to execute with the item URI and title.
//       openUriInASpecialTab(result.clickUri, result.title);
//     }
//   }
// });

name: PrintableUri.options.openInOutlook
comment:
Specifies whether the component should try to open its link in Microsoft Outlook. Setting this option to true is normally useful for ResultLink instances related to Microsoft Exchange emails.

If this option is true, clicking the ResultLink calls the openLinkInOutlook method instead of the openLink method.

Default value is false.

name: PrintableUri.options.openQuickview
comment: Specifies whether the component should open its link in the Quickview component rather than loading through the original URL. Default value is false.

name: PrintableUri.options.titleTemplate
comment:
Specifies a template literal from which to generate the ResultLink display title (see Template literals). This option overrides the default ResultLink display title behavior.

The template literal can reference any number of fields from the parent result. However, if the template literal references a key whose value is undefined in the parent result fields, the ResultLink title displays the name of this key instead.

This option is ignored if the ResultLink innerHTML contains any value.

Examples:

  • The following markup generates a ResultLink display title such as Case number: 123456 if both the raw.objecttype and raw.objectnumber keys are defined in the parent result fields:
<a class="CoveoResultLink" data-title-template="${raw.objecttype} number: ${raw.objectnumber}"></a>
  • The following markup generates ${myField} as a ResultLink display title if the myField key is undefined in the parent result fields:
<a class="CoveoResultLink" data-title-template="${myField}"></a>
  • The following markup generates Foobar as a ResultLink display title, because the ResultLink innterHTML is not empty:
<a class="CoveoResultLink" data-title-template="${will} ${be} ${ignored}">Foobar</a>

Default value is undefined.

name: PrintableUri.bind
comment: Allows the component to bind events and execute them only when it is enabled.

name: PrintableUri.componentOptionsModel
comment: Contains the state of options for differents component. Mainly used by ResultLink.

name: PrintableUri.componentStateModel
comment: Contains the state of different component (enabled vs disabled). Allows to get/set values. Trigger component state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: PrintableUri.disabled
comment: A disabled component will not participate in the query, or listen to ComponentEvents.

name: PrintableUri.logger
comment: Allows component to log in the dev console.

name: PrintableUri.queryController
comment: Contains the singleton that allows to trigger queries.

name: PrintableUri.queryStateModel
comment: Contains the state of the query. Allows to get/set values. Trigger query state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: PrintableUri.root
comment: A reference to the root HTMLElement (the SearchInterface).

name: PrintableUri.searchInterface
comment: A reference to the root of every component, the SearchInterface.

name: PrintableUri.usageAnalytics
comment: A reference to the Analytics.client.

name: PrintableUri.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component need to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: PrintableUri.constructor
comment: Creates a new PrintableUri.

name: QueryBuilder
comment:
The QueryBuilder is used to build a IQuery that will be able to be executed using the Search API.
The class exposes several members and methods that help components and external code to build up the final query that is sent to the Search API.

name: QueryBuilder.actionsHistory
comment: The actions history represents the past actions a user made and is used by the Coveo Machine Learning service to suggest recommendations. It is generated by the page view script (https://github.com/coveo/coveo.analytics.js).

name: QueryBuilder.advancedExpression
comment:
Used to build the advanced part of the query expression.
This part is typically formed of filter expressions generated by components such as facets, external code, etc.

name: QueryBuilder.childField
comment: Specifies the childField when doing parent-child loading (See : Folding).

name: QueryBuilder.constantExpression
comment:
Used to build the advanced part of the query expression.
This part is similar to advancedExpression, but its content is interpreted as a constant expression by the index and it takes advantage of special caching features.

name: QueryBuilder.context
comment: The context is a map of key_value that can be used in the Query pipeline in the Coveo platform.

name: QueryBuilder.disjunctionExpression
comment:
Used to build the disjunctive part of the query expression.
When present, this part is evaluated separately from the other expressions and the matching results are merged to those matching expressions, advancedExpression and constantExpression.
The final boolean expression for the query is thus (basic advanced constant) OR (disjunction).

name: QueryBuilder.enableCollaborativeRating
comment: Whether the index should take collaborative rating in account when ranking result (see : ResultRating).

name: QueryBuilder.enableDebug
comment:
Whether to enable debug info on the query.
This will return additional information on the resulting JSON response from the Search API.
Mostly: execution report (a detailed breakdown of the parsed and executed query).

name: QueryBuilder.enableDidYouMean
comment: Whether to enable query corrections on this query (see DidYouMean).

name: QueryBuilder.enableLowercaseOperators
comment: Whether to enable the support for operator in lowercase (AND OR -> and or).

name: QueryBuilder.enablePartialMatch
comment:
Whether to enable partial matching of the basic expression keywords.
By activating this, when the basic expression contains at least IQuery.partialMatchKeywords, items containing only the number of keywords specified by IQuery.partialMatchThreshold will also match the query.
Without this option, items are required to contain all the keywords in order to match the query.
If not specified, this parameter defaults to false.

name: QueryBuilder.enableQuerySyntax
comment: Whether to enable the special query syntax such as field references for the basic query expression (parameter q). It is equivalent to a No syntax block applied to the basic query expression. If not specified, the parameter defaults to false.

name: QueryBuilder.enableQuestionMarks
comment:
Whether to enable question marks with wildcards.
This enables using the question mark ? character within wildcard expressions.

name: QueryBuilder.enableWildcards
comment:
Whether to enable wildcards on the basic expression keywords.
This enables the wildcard features of the index. Coveo Platform will expand keywords containing wildcard characters to the possible matching keywords to broaden the query.
(see : https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/ces/7.0/user/using_wildcards_in_queries.htm).
If not specified, this parameter defaults to false.

name: QueryBuilder.excerptLength
comment:
This specifies the length (in number of characters) of the excerpts generated by the indexer based on the keywords present in the query.
The index includes the top most interesting sentences (in the order they appear in the item) that fit in the specified number of characters.
When not specified, the default value is 200.

name: QueryBuilder.expression
comment:
Used to build the basic part of the query expression.
This part typically consists of user-entered content such as query keywords, etc.

name: QueryBuilder.filterField
comment:
This specifies a field on which Folding should be performed.
Folding is a kind of duplicate filtering where only the first result with any given value of the field is included in the result set.
It's typically used to return only one result in a conversation, for example when forum posts in a thread are indexed as separate items.

name: QueryBuilder.filterFieldRange
comment: Number of results that should be folded, using the IQuery.filterField.

name: QueryBuilder.firstResult
comment:
This is the 0-based index of the first result to return.
If not specified, this parameter defaults to 0.

name: QueryBuilder.groupByRequests
comment: This specifies an array of Group By operations that can be performed on the query results to extract facets.

name: QueryBuilder.longQueryExpression
comment:
The contextual text.
This is the contextual text part of the query. It uses the Coveo Machine Learning service to pick key keywords from the text and add them to the basic expression. This field is mainly used to pass context such a case description, long textual query or any other form of text that might help in refining the query.

name: QueryBuilder.maximumAge
comment:
The maximum age for cached query results, in milliseconds.
If results for the exact same request (including user identities) are available in the in-memory cache, they will be used if they are not older than the specified value.
Otherwise, the query will be sent to the index.

name: QueryBuilder.numberOfResults
comment:
This is the number of results to return, starting from IQuery.firstResult.
If not specified, this parameter defaults to 10.

name: QueryBuilder.parentField
comment: Specifies the parentField when doing parent-child loading (See : Folding).

name: QueryBuilder.partialMatchKeywords
comment:
The minimum number of keywords needed to activate partial match.
This specifies the minimum number of keywords needed for the partial match feature to activate.
If the basic expression contains less than this number of keywords, no transformation is applied on the query.
If not specified, this parameter defaults to 5.

name: QueryBuilder.partialMatchThreshold
comment:
The threshold to use for matching items when partial match is enabled.
This specifies the minimum number of query keywords that an item must contain when partial match is enabled. This value can either be an absolute number or a percentage value based on the total number of keywords.
If not specified, this parameter defaults to 50%.

name: QueryBuilder.pipeline
comment:
Name of the query pipeline to use.
This specifies the name of the query pipeline to use for the query. If not specified, the default value is default, which means the default query pipeline will be used.

name: QueryBuilder.queryFunctions
comment: This specifies an array of Query Function operation that will be executed on the results.

name: QueryBuilder.rankingFunctions
comment: This specifies an array of Ranking Function operations that will be executed on the results.

name: QueryBuilder.recommendation
comment: This is the ID of the recommendation interface that generated the query.

name: QueryBuilder.searchHub
comment:
The hub value set from the Analytics component.
Used for analytics reporting in the Coveo platform.

name: QueryBuilder.sortCriteria
comment:
This specifies the sort criterion(s) to use to sort results. If not specified, this parameter defaults to relevancy.
Possible values are :
-- relevancy : This uses all the configured ranking weights as well as any specified ranking expressions to rank results.
-- dateascending / datedescending Sort using the value of the @date field, which is typically the last modification date of an item in the index.
-- qre : Sort using only the weights applied through ranking expressions. This is much like using relevancy except that automatic weights based on keyword proximity etc, are not computed.
-- nosort : Do not sort the results. The order in which items are returned is essentially random.
-- @field ascending / @field descending Sort using the value of a custom field.

name: QueryBuilder.tab
comment: The tab value set from the Tab component.

name: QueryController
comment:
This class is automatically instantiated and bound to the root of your search interface when you initialize the framework.
It is essentially a singleton that wraps the access to the SearchEndpoint endpoint to execute query, and is in charge of triggering the different query events.
This is what every component of the framework uses internally to execute query or access the endpoint.
When calling Coveo.executeQuery this class is used.

name: QueryController.disabled
comment: A disabled component will not participate in the query, or listen to ComponentEvents.

name: QueryController.logger
comment: Allows component to log in the dev console.

name: QueryController.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component need to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: QueryController.constructor
comment: Create a new query controller

name: QueryEvents
comment: This static class is there to contains the different string definition for all the events related to query. Note that these events will only be triggered when the QueryController.executeQuery method is used, either directly or by using executeQuery

name: QueryEvents.buildingQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is being built. This is typically where all components will contribute their part to the IQuery using the QueryBuilder.

All bound handlers will receive IBuildingQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is buildingQuery.

name: QueryEvents.deferredQuerySuccess
comment:
Triggered after the main query success event has finished executing. This is typically where facets will process the IGroupByResult and render themselves.

All bound handlers will receive IQuerySuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is deferredQuerySuccess.

name: QueryEvents.doneBuildingQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is done being built. This is typically where the facet will add it's IGroupByRequest to the IQuery.

All bound handlers will receive IDoneBuildingQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is doneBuildingQuery.

name: QueryEvents.duringFetchMoreQuery
comment:
Triggered when more results are being fetched on the Search API (think : infinite scrolling, or pager). All bound handlers will receive IDuringQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is duringFetchMoreQuery.

name: QueryEvents.duringQuery
comment:
Triggered when the query is being executed on the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IDuringQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is duringQuery.

name: QueryEvents.fetchMoreSuccess
comment:
Triggered when a more results were successfully returned from the Search API. (think : infinite scrolling, or pager). All bound handlers will receive IFetchMoreSuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is fetchMoreSuccess.

name: QueryEvents.newQuery
comment:
Triggered when a new query is launched. All bound handlers will receive INewQueryEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is newQuery.

name: QueryEvents.noResults
comment:
Triggered when there is no result for a particular query. All bound handlers will receive INoResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is noResults.

name: QueryEvents.preprocessMoreResults
comment:
Triggered before the QueryEvents.fetchMoreSuccess event. This allows external code to modify the results before rendering them.

For example, the Folding component might use this event to construct a coherent parent child relationship between query results.

All bound handlers will receive IPreprocessResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is preprocessMoreResults.

name: QueryEvents.preprocessResults
comment:
Triggered before the QueryEvents.querySuccess event. This allows external code to modify the results before rendering them.

For example, the Folding component might use this event to construct a coherent parent child relationship between query results.

All bound handlers will receive IPreprocessResultsEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is preprocessResults.

name: QueryEvents.queryError
comment:
Triggered when there was an error executing a query on the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IQueryErrorEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is queryError.

name: QueryEvents.querySuccess
comment:
Triggered when a query successfully returns from the Search API. All bound handlers will receive IQuerySuccessEventArgs as an argument.

The string value is querySuccess.

name: QueryStateModel
comment:
The QueryStateModel is a key->value store of the state of every component that can affect a query.
Component set values in this key -> value store, and listen to event triggered to react accordingly.
For example, when a query is launched, the searchbox will set the 'q' attribute, the pager will set the 'first' attribute, etc.
At the same time, this class will trigger the associated event when a value is modified.
eg : The user change the content of the searchbox, and submit a query. This will trigger the following events :
-- state:change:q (because the value of 'q' changed)
-- state:change (because at least one value changed in the query state)
Component or external code could hook handler on those events : document.addEventListener('state:change:q', handler);
See : Model, as all the relevant method are exposed in the base class.
Optionally, the state can be persisted to the query string to allow browser history management : See HistoryController

name: QueryStateModel.attributes
comment:
The attributes contained in this model.
Normally, you should not set attributes directly on this property, as this would prevent required events from being triggered.

name: QueryStateModel.disabled
comment: A disabled component will not participate in the query, or listen to ComponentEvents.

name: QueryStateModel.logger
comment: Allows component to log in the dev console.

name: QueryStateModel.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component need to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: QueryStateModel.eventTypes
comment:
The event types that can be triggered:
preprocess: triggered before a value is set on an attribute. This allows the value to be modified before it is set.
changeOne: triggered when a single value changes.
change: triggered when one or many values change.
reset: triggered when all attributes are reset to their default values.
all: triggered after the change event.

name: QueryStateModel.constructor
comment: Create a new QueryState

name: QuerySummaryEvents
comment: This static class is there to contains the different string definition for all the events related to the AdvancedSearch component.

name: QuerySummaryEvents.cancelLastAction
comment: Triggered when the last action is being cancelled by the query summary component Allows external code to revert their last action.

name: RadioButton
comment: A radio button widget with standard styling.

name: RadioButton.constructor
comment: Creates a new RadioButton.

name: ResponsiveComponents
comment:
This class serves as a way to get and set the different screen size breakpoints for the interface. By settings those, you can impact, amongst other, the Facet, Tab or ResultList behaviour.

For example, the Facet components of your interface will switch to a dropdown menu when the screen size reaches 800px or less.

You could modify this value using this calls

Normally, you would interact with this class using the instance bound to SearchInterface.responsiveComponents

name: SearchEndpoint
comment:
The SearchEndpoint class allows you to execute various actions against the Coveo Search API and a Coveo index (e.g., searching, listing field values, getting the quickview content of an item, etc.). This class does trigger any query events directly. Consequently, executing an action with this class does not trigger a full query cycle for the Coveo components.

If you wish to have all Coveo components "react" to a query, (and trigger the corresponding query events), use the QueryController class instead.

name: SearchEndpoint.endpoints
comment:
Contains a map of all initialized SearchEndpoint instances. Example:

Coveo.SearchEndpoint.endpoints['default'] returns the default endpoint that was created at initialization.

name: SearchEndpoint.constructor
comment: Creates a new SearchEndpoint instance. Uses a set of adequate default options, and merges these with the options parameter. Also creates an EndpointCaller instance and uses it to communicate with the endpoint internally.

name: TemplateCache
comment: Holds a reference to all template available in the framework

name: TemplateHelpers
comment: Allow to register and return template helpers (essentially: Utility functions that can be executed in the context of a template to render complex elements).

name: TextInput
comment: A text input widget with standard styling.

name: TextInput.constructor
comment: Creates a new TextInput.

name: IAdvancedSearchSection
comment: Describe a section in the AdvancedSearch component

name: IAdvancedSearchSection.inputs
comment: The array of inputs to populate. External code should only push inputs that match the type BaseFormTypes.

name: IAdvancedSearchSection.name
comment: The name of the section.

name: IAnalyticsActionCause
comment: The IAnalyticsActionCause interface describes the cause of an event for the analytics service. See the Analytics component

name: IAnalyticsActionCause.name
comment: Specifies the name of the event. While you can actually set this property to any arbitrary string value, its value should uniquely identify the precise action that triggers the event. Thus, each individual event should have its own unique name value. Example: searchBoxSubmit, resultSort, etc.

name: IAnalyticsActionCause.type
comment: Specifies the type of the event. While you can actually set this property to any arbitrary string value, it should describe the general category of the event. Thus, more than one event can have the same type value, which makes it possible to group events with identical types when doing reporting. Example: All search box related events could have searchbox as their type value.

name: IAnalyticsClient
comment: The IAnalyticsClient interface describes an analytics client that can log events to, or return information from the usage analytics service. See also the Analytics component.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta
comment: The IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta interface describes the expected metadata when logging a click event / item view. See also the Analytics component, and more specifically its logClickEvent method.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.author
comment: The author of the clicked item.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.documentTitle
comment: The title of the clicked item.

name: IAnalyticsDocumentViewMeta.documentURL
comment: The URL of the clicked item.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions
comment: Options for building an <a> tag.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.class
comment: The CSS class(es) of the tag.

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.target
comment: The target (href attribute).

name: IAnchorUtilsOptions.text
comment: The tag's text content.

name: IBadgeColors
comment: Badge Colors

name: IBreadcrumbItem
comment: Represent an item to insert in the breadcrumb

name: IBreadcrumbItem.element
comment: The HTMLElement to insert in the breadcrumb

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on AdvancedSearchEvents.buildingAdvancedSearch

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs.executeQuery
comment: An easy way to execute a new query.

name: IBuildingAdvancedSearchEventArgs.sections
comment: Sections which external code can populate by pushing into this array.

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs
comment: Argument sent to all handlers bound on QueryEvents.buildingQuery

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.cancel
comment: If this property is set to true by any handlers, the query will not be executed.

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.queryBuilder
comment: Allow handlers to modify the query by using the QueryBuilder

name: IBuildingQueryEventArgs.searchAsYouType
comment: Determine if the query is a "search as you type"

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs
comment:
Argument sent to all handlers bound on AnalyticsEvents.changeAnalyticsCustomData. It extends the IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject interface.

Take note that only the attributes described by IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject can be modified by external code.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.actionCause
comment:
The cause of the event. All analytics events triggered by a different component will use a different action cause.

For example, triggering a query by using the search box will send a searchBoxSubmit actionCause.

Triggering a query with a facet selection, on the other hand, will send a facetSelect.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.actionType
comment:
The type of the event. The type is normally a generic string that regroups all events triggered by the same feature or component.

For example, all analytics events related to the Searchbox will all use the same actionType.

Analytics events related to Facets, on the other hand, would use a different actionType.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.language
comment: The language of the search interface. By default, this will be populated by the currently loaded localization and culture file for the search interface.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.metaObject
comment: The metadata for the current event. External code can modify an existing value, or add a new key - value pair.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel1
comment:
The originLevel1 property can be used to describe the high level origin of the event. For example, this can be the location of the search page, or any name that allows you to uniquely identify a search interface.

If not provided, this value will be default.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel2
comment: The originLevel2 property can be used to describe the mid level origin of the event. By default, the framework will populate this with the currently selected tab.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.originLevel3
comment: The originLevel3 property can be used to describe the low level origin of the event. By default, this property will be left empty.

name: IChangeAnalyticsCustomDataEventArgs.type
comment: The type of the event that was just triggered. This can help external code to discriminate the event that it wishes to modify.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject
comment: The interface that describe part of the analytics event that can be modified.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.language
comment: The language of the search interface. By default, this will be populated by the currently loaded localization and culture file for the search interface.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.metaObject
comment: The metadata for the current event. External code can modify an existing value, or add a new key - value pair.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel1
comment:
The originLevel1 property can be used to describe the high level origin of the event. For example, this can be the location of the search page, or any name that allows you to uniquely identify a search interface.

If not provided, this value will be default.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel2
comment: The originLevel2 property can be used to describe the mid level origin of the event. By default, the framework will populate this with the currently selected tab.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsDataObject.originLevel3
comment: The originLevel3 property can be used to describe the low level origin of the event. By default, this property will be left empty.

name: IChangeableAnalyticsMetaObject
comment: The interface that describe the metadata for every analytics event.

name: IComponentBindings
comment: The bindings, or environment in which each component exists.

name: IComponentBindings.componentOptionsModel
comment: Contains the state of options for different components. Mainly used by ResultLink.

name: IComponentBindings.componentStateModel
comment: Contains the state of different components (enabled vs disabled). Allows to get/set values. Triggers component state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: IComponentBindings.queryController
comment: Contains the singleton that allows to trigger queries.

name: IComponentBindings.queryStateModel
comment: Contains the state of the query. Allows to get/set values. Triggers state event when modified. Each component can listen to those events.

name: IComponentBindings.root
comment: The root HTMLElement of the SearchInterface in which the component exists.

name: IComponentBindings.searchInterface
comment: A reference to the root of every component, the SearchInterface.

name: IComponentBindings.usageAnalytics
comment: A reference to the Analytics.client.

name: IComponentDefinition
comment: Definition for a Component.

name: IComponentDefinition.ID
comment:
The static ID that each component need to be identified.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: IComponentDefinition.className
comment:
The generated className for this component.
For example, SearchButton -> static ID : SearchButton -> className : CoveoSearchButton

name: IComponentDefinition.doExport
comment: Function that can be called to export one or multiple module in the global scope.

name: IComponentDefinition.fields
comment: The optional index fields that the component possess or display.

name: IComponentDefinition.options
comment: The available options for the component.

name: IComponentDefinition.parent
comment: The optional parent of the component, which will be a component itself.

name: IComponentDefinition.constructor
comment: Constructor for each component

name: IComponentOptions
comment: This represent the possible parameters that can be used to configure an option

name: IComponentOptions.alias
comment: Allow to specify an alias for an option name. This can be useful to modify the name of an option without introducing a breaking change.

name: IComponentOptions.attrName
comment: Allow to specify a different markup name for an option than the default value. Using this is extremely rare, and should be used only for legacy reasons.

name: IComponentOptions.defaultFunction
comment: Specify a function which should return the default value that should be given to the option if it is not specified.

name: IComponentOptions.defaultValue
comment: Specify the default value that should be given to the option if it is not specified.

name: IComponentOptions.depend
comment: Specify that an option depend on another option being enabled. Mostly useful for the interface editor.

name: IComponentOptions.deprecated
comment:
Specify that an option is deprecated. This string will be displayed in the console on initialization.

The message should be as clear as possible as to why this option is deprecated, and how it can be replaced.

This also mean that the option will not appear in the interface editor.

name: IComponentOptions.postProcessing
comment: Specify a function which can be used to further modify the value for a given option after all other options have been loaded. For example, the Facet.options.id will use this to set the default ID with the same value as the Facet.options.field.

name: IComponentOptions.required
comment: Specify if the option is "required" so that the component can do it's job properly. For example, the Facet.options.field is required, as a facet with no field cannot function.

name: IComponentOptions.section
comment: Specify a section name inside which the option should appear in the interface editor.

name: IComponentOptions.validator
comment: Specify a function which can be used to verify the validity of the option. The function should return true if the option is valid, false otherwise.
